markdownRemark.html:
What Are Monte Carlo Policy Gradients in Reinforcement Learning, and How Do They Function? Can You Break Down the Mechanism Using a Detailed Numerical Example for Better Understanding?ğŸ”—

Monte Carlo Policy Gradients (REINFORCE)ğŸ”—

The REINFORCE algorithm is one of the most basic policy gradient methods. It uses Monte Carlo sampling to estimate the expected return, and then leverages this to adjust the policy.

Main Idea: After each episode, adjust the weights of your policy in a direction that would make the taken actions more probable if they resulted in good rewards, and less probable if they resulted in bad rewards.

Steps:

  1. Use the current policy to collect an episode: {s0,a0,r1,s1,a1,r2,...,sT}\{s_0, a_0, r_1, s_1, a_1, r_2, ..., s_T\}{s0â€‹,a0â€‹,r1â€‹,s1â€‹,a1â€‹,r2â€‹,...,sTâ€‹}.
  2. For each time step ttt in the episode:
    • Compute the return GtG_tGtâ€‹ from that time step onwards.
    • Update the policy parameters Î¸\thetaÎ¸ using the policy gradient update rule.

Equations:ğŸ”—

  1. Return:

Gt=rt+1+Î³rt+2+Î³2rt+3+...G_t = r_{t+1} + \gamma r_{t+2} + \gamma^2 r_{t+3} + ...Gtâ€‹=rt+1â€‹+Î³rt+2â€‹+Î³2rt+3â€‹+... where Î³\gammaÎ³ is the discount factor.

  1. Policy Gradient Update:

Î¸â†Î¸+Î±âˆ‡Î¸logâ¡Ï€Î¸(atâˆ£st)Gt\theta \leftarrow \theta + \alpha \nabla_\theta \log \pi_\theta(a_t|s_t) G_tÎ¸â†Î¸+Î±âˆ‡Î¸â€‹logÏ€Î¸â€‹(atâ€‹âˆ£stâ€‹)Gtâ€‹ where:

  • Î±\alphaÎ± is the learning rate.
  • âˆ‡Î¸logâ¡Ï€Î¸(atâˆ£st)\nabla_\theta \log \pi_\theta(a_t|s_t)âˆ‡Î¸â€‹logÏ€Î¸â€‹(atâ€‹âˆ£stâ€‹) is the gradient of the log probability of the action taken at time ttt, with respect to the policy parameters Î¸\thetaÎ¸.

Numerical Example:ğŸ”—

Consider a simple game where an agent can move in a 1D environment, from leftmost position 0 to the rightmost position 10. The goal is to reach position 10.

Actions: Move left or move right.

Rewards: +1 for reaching position 10, 0 otherwise.

Policy:

  • Represented by a neural network.
  • Input: Current position.
  • Output: Probability of moving right. (1 minus this is the probability of moving left.)

Let's say after an episode, the agent took the following actions from positions:

s0=0â†’a0=rightâ†’s1=1â†’a1=rightâ†’s2=2s_0 = 0 \to a_0 = \text{right} \to s_1 = 1 \to a_1 = \text{right} \to s_2 = 2s0â€‹=0â†’a0â€‹=rightâ†’s1â€‹=1â†’a1â€‹=rightâ†’s2â€‹=2

The episode ended without reaching the goal.

For each time step:

  1. At t=0t = 0t=0:

    • G0=0G_0 = 0G0â€‹=0 (since no reward was received in this episode)
    • If the policy Ï€Î¸(a0âˆ£s0)=0.6\pi_\theta(a_0|s_0) = 0.6Ï€Î¸â€‹(a0â€‹âˆ£s0â€‹)=0.6 (60% probability to move right at position 0):

    Î¸â†Î¸+Î±âˆ‡Î¸logâ¡(0.6)Ã—0\theta \leftarrow \theta + \alpha \nabla_\theta \log(0.6) \times 0Î¸â†Î¸+Î±âˆ‡Î¸â€‹log(0.6)Ã—0 (This doesn't change Î¸\thetaÎ¸ since G0=0G_0 = 0G0â€‹=0)

  2. At t=1t = 1t=1:

    • Similarly, G1=0G_1 = 0G1â€‹=0
    • If Ï€Î¸(a1âˆ£s1)=0.55\pi_\theta(a_1|s_1) = 0.55Ï€Î¸â€‹(a1â€‹âˆ£s1â€‹)=0.55:

    Î¸â†Î¸+Î±âˆ‡Î¸logâ¡(0.55)Ã—0\theta \leftarrow \theta + \alpha \nabla_\theta \log(0.55) \times 0Î¸â†Î¸+Î±âˆ‡Î¸â€‹log(0.55)Ã—0

This process helps the agent learn a policy that increases the likelihood of actions that lead to higher returns and decreases the likelihood of actions that don't.

In a subsequent episode, if the agent reaches the goal and gets a reward, the policy will be adjusted in a direction that makes the taken actions more probable.

How Do Constrained Policy Gradients Operate in Reinforcement Learning, and How Do They Differ from Monte Carlo Policy Gradients? Can You Illustrate the Distinctive Features and Mechanism of Constrained Policy Gradients Using a Numerical Example?ğŸ”—

Constrained Policy Gradients (CPG) introduce an additional constraint to the optimization process of policy gradient methods. The aim is to ensure that the new policy doesn't deviate too much from the old one. By doing this, we maintain some stability in the learning process.

The key difference between standard policy gradients and constrained policy gradients is the introduction of a constraint on the policy updates. This constraint can prevent large policy changes, which can lead to policy collapse or other instability issues in learning.

KL Divergence:ğŸ”—

One popular method to ensure that policies don't change too drastically is to use the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence. It's a measure of how one probability distribution is different from a second, reference probability distribution.

In the context of Constrained Policy Gradients, we aim to minimize the expected return (like in standard policy gradient methods) but with an additional constraint that the KL divergence between the new and old policy should be less than some threshold.

Objective:ğŸ”—

maximizeJ(Î¸)\text{maximize} \quad J(\theta)maximizeJ(Î¸) subjectÂ toDKL(Ï€Î¸old(â‹…âˆ£s)âˆ£âˆ£Ï€Î¸(â‹…âˆ£s))â‰¤Î´,forÂ allÂ s\text{subject to} \quad D_{KL}(\pi_{\theta_{old}}(\cdot|s) || \pi_\theta(\cdot|s)) \leq \delta, \text{for all } ssubjectÂ toDKLâ€‹(Ï€Î¸oldâ€‹â€‹(â‹…âˆ£s)âˆ£âˆ£Ï€Î¸â€‹(â‹…âˆ£s))â‰¤Î´,forÂ allÂ s

Where:

  • J(Î¸)J(\theta)J(Î¸) is the expected return.
  • Ï€Î¸old\pi_{\theta_{old}}Ï€Î¸oldâ€‹â€‹ is the old policy.
  • Ï€Î¸\pi_{\theta}Ï€Î¸â€‹ is the new policy.
  • Î´\deltaÎ´ is a small positive threshold.

Numerical Example:ğŸ”—

Let's go back to our simple 1D game. Assume we've already trained a bit, and our current policy, Ï€Î¸old\pi_{\theta_{old}}Ï€Î¸oldâ€‹â€‹, gives us a 70% probability of moving right from position 0.

After computing policy gradients and applying them, our new policy, Ï€Î¸\pi_\thetaÏ€Î¸â€‹, gives us an 85% chance of moving right from position 0.

Now, we check the KL divergence between these two policies for this state:

DKL(Ï€Î¸old(â‹…âˆ£0)âˆ£âˆ£Ï€Î¸(â‹…âˆ£0))D_{KL}(\pi_{\theta_{old}}(\cdot|0) || \pi_\theta(\cdot|0))DKLâ€‹(Ï€Î¸oldâ€‹â€‹(â‹…âˆ£0)âˆ£âˆ£Ï€Î¸â€‹(â‹…âˆ£0))

Assume this gives a value of 0.1. If our threshold Î´\deltaÎ´ is set to 0.05, this means our policy update was too big. In such a case, we would need to scale down our policy update to ensure that the KL divergence constraint is satisfied.

Constrained Policy Gradients, like the one mentioned above, are a foundation for more advanced methods like Trust Region Policy Optimization (TRPO) and Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO), which use similar principles to ensure stable policy updates. The idea is to strike a balance: we want to improve our policy, but we don't want to change it so much that we lose all the knowledge we've gained from previous interactions with the environment.

The Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence is a measure of how one probability distribution differs from a second, reference probability distribution. It's not symmetric, meaning DKL(Pâˆ£âˆ£Q)â‰ DKL(Qâˆ£âˆ£P)D_{KL}(P || Q) \neq D_{KL}(Q || P)DKLâ€‹(Pâˆ£âˆ£Q)î€ =DKLâ€‹(Qâˆ£âˆ£P).

The formula for the KL divergence of two discrete probability distributions PPP and QQQ is given by:

DKL(Pâˆ£âˆ£Q)=âˆ‘iP(i)logâ¡P(i)Q(i)D_{KL}(P || Q) = \sum_{i} P(i) \log \frac{P(i)}{Q(i)}DKLâ€‹(Pâˆ£âˆ£Q)=iâˆ‘â€‹P(i)logQ(i)P(i)â€‹

Where:

  • P(i)P(i)P(i) is the probability of event iii according to distribution PPP.
  • Q(i)Q(i)Q(i) is the probability of event iii according to distribution QQQ.

Let's work through a numerical example:

Example:ğŸ”—

Suppose you have two probability distributions over a three-event space:

P=[0.2,0.5,0.3]P = [0.2, 0.5, 0.3]P=[0.2,0.5,0.3] Q=[0.1,0.6,0.3]Q = [0.1, 0.6, 0.3]Q=[0.1,0.6,0.3]

Here, the events could represent anything â€“ for instance, the likelihood of observing "red", "green", or "blue" from two different systems or experiments.

To compute DKL(Pâˆ£âˆ£Q)D_{KL}(P || Q)DKLâ€‹(Pâˆ£âˆ£Q):

  1. For the first event:

P(1)logâ¡P(1)Q(1)=0.2logâ¡0.20.1P(1) \log \frac{P(1)}{Q(1)} = 0.2 \log \frac{0.2}{0.1}P(1)logQ(1)P(1)â€‹=0.2log0.10.2â€‹

  1. For the second event:

P(2)logâ¡P(2)Q(2)=0.5logâ¡0.50.6P(2) \log \frac{P(2)}{Q(2)} = 0.5 \log \frac{0.5}{0.6}P(2)logQ(2)P(2)â€‹=0.5log0.60.5â€‹

  1. For the third event:

P(3)logâ¡P(3)Q(3)=0.3logâ¡0.30.3P(3) \log \frac{P(3)}{Q(3)} = 0.3 \log \frac{0.3}{0.3}P(3)logQ(3)P(3)â€‹=0.3log0.30.3â€‹

Summing these values will give DKL(Pâˆ£âˆ£Q)D_{KL}(P || Q)DKLâ€‹(Pâˆ£âˆ£Q).

The KL divergence DKL(Pâˆ£âˆ£Q)D_{KL}(P || Q)DKLâ€‹(Pâˆ£âˆ£Q) for the given distributions PPP and QQQ is approximately 0.04750.04750.0475. This means that distribution PPP is this amount "away" from distribution QQQ in terms of their divergence. The higher this value, the more different the two distributions are from each other.

It's worth noting that if PPP was exactly the same as QQQ, the KL divergence would be zero, indicating no divergence between the two distributions.

This metric is crucial in many applications of machine learning, especially in variational inference, where it measures the divergence between the approximating distribution and the true posterior distribution.

Actor-Critic Architecture.ğŸ”—

  1. Action Selection by Actor: You're correct that when the actor is in state 3 and the state is passed to the actor network (policy approximator), it outputs a probability distribution over all actions. We either take the action with the highest probability (greedy action) or sample an action based on this distribution.

  2. Interaction with Environment: After selecting action bbb, the agent interacts with the environment and receives a reward and transitions to the next state (let's call it state sâ€²s'sâ€²).

  3. Critic's Role: Here's where the clarification is needed:

    • The critic evaluates the value of states, not state-action pairs (unless you're using a Q-function critic, but for our discussion, let's assume it's a Value-function critic).
    • When you mentioned "we give action and state 3 and action bbb to the critic", that's not quite right for a standard actor-critic method. Instead, you provide only the state (state 3 in this case) to the critic, and it outputs the estimated value of that state.
    • After the agent transitions to the next state sâ€²s'sâ€², you again provide this state sâ€²s'sâ€² to the critic to get its estimated value.

  4. Updating the Critic: The critic is updated using the Temporal Difference (TD) error:

    TDÂ error=reward+Î³Ã—Criticâ€™sÂ valueÂ ofÂ sâ€²âˆ’Criticâ€™sÂ valueÂ ofÂ stateÂ 3\text{TD error} = \text{reward} + \gamma \times \text{Critic's value of } s' - \text{Critic's value of state 3}TDÂ error=reward+Î³Ã—Criticâ€™sÂ valueÂ ofÂ sâ€²âˆ’Criticâ€™sÂ valueÂ ofÂ stateÂ 3

    The critic then updates its weights to minimize this TD error.

  5. Updating the Actor: The actor is updated using the TD error from the critic. If the TD error is positive, it means the chosen action bbb in state 3 was better than what the critic initially expected, and thus the actor should increase the probability of choosing action bbb in the future when in state 3. Conversely, if the TD error is negative, the actor should decrease the probability of choosing action bbb when in state 3.

The entire process is iterative and continues until the policy converges to an optimal or near-optimal policy.

What is Advantage Function, Explain it.ğŸ”—

The Advantage Function plays a crucial role in many reinforcement learning algorithms. Let's break it down step by step.

Definition:ğŸ”—

The Advantage Function, often denoted as A(s,a)A(s, a)A(s,a), measures how much better an action aaa is compared to the average action in state sss. In other words, it tells us the advantage of taking a particular action over others in a given state.

Equation:ğŸ”—

The Advantage Function is typically defined as:

A(s,a)=Q(s,a)âˆ’V(s)A(s, a) = Q(s, a) - V(s)A(s,a)=Q(s,a)âˆ’V(s)

Where:

  • Q(s,a)Q(s, a)Q(s,a) is the action-value function that tells us the expected return of taking action aaa in state sss.
  • V(s)V(s)V(s) is the value function that tells us the expected return of state sss, considering we follow the current policy.

Why use it?ğŸ”—

  1. Bias-Variance Trade-off: The advantage function can help in balancing the bias-variance trade-off. Using only the action-value function Q(s,a)Q(s, a)Q(s,a) can lead to high variance in updates, especially with function approximators like neural networks. Subtracting the state value V(s)V(s)V(s) can help reduce this variance.

  2. Clearer Policy Gradient Signal: By using the advantage function in policy gradient methods, we get a clearer signal on how much better (or worse) an action is compared to the average. This can lead to more stable and efficient policy updates.

  3. Facilitates Exploration: Using the advantage function can help in distinguishing actions that are only slightly better than others, which can guide exploration in action spaces.

Numerical Example:ğŸ”—

Imagine you're training an agent to play a simple game. The agent is in a state sss and has two actions: a1a_1a1â€‹ and a2a_2a2â€‹.

Let's say:

  • Q(s,a1)=10Q(s, a_1) = 10Q(s,a1â€‹)=10: The expected return when taking action a1a_1a1â€‹ in state sss.
  • Q(s,a2)=8Q(s, a_2) = 8Q(s,a2â€‹)=8: The expected return when taking action a2a_2a2â€‹ in state sss.
  • V(s)=9V(s) = 9V(s)=9: The expected return of state sss when following the current policy.

From the above, the advantage of taking action a1a_1a1â€‹ in state sss is:

A(s,a1)=Q(s,a1)âˆ’V(s)=10âˆ’9=1A(s, a_1) = Q(s, a_1) - V(s) = 10 - 9 = 1A(s,a1â€‹)=Q(s,a1â€‹)âˆ’V(s)=10âˆ’9=1

And the advantage of taking action a2a_2a2â€‹ is:

A(s,a2)=Q(s,a2)âˆ’V(s)=8âˆ’9=âˆ’1A(s, a_2) = Q(s, a_2) - V(s) = 8 - 9 = -1A(s,a2â€‹)=Q(s,a2â€‹)âˆ’V(s)=8âˆ’9=âˆ’1

This tells us that action a1a_1a1â€‹ is better than the average action in state sss by a value of 1, while action a2a_2a2â€‹ is worse than average by a value of 1.

Problem it solves:ğŸ”—

Without the advantage function, if we were to update our policy using just the raw action values Q(s,a)Q(s, a)Q(s,a), the agent might overestimate the relative importance of actions in states where all actions are good (or all are bad). By centering our updates around the average value of the state V(s)V(s)V(s), the agent gets a clearer picture of which actions are better or worse relative to the average action in that state.

frontmatter.title: Reinforcement Part 3
frontmatter.author: Gaurav
frontmatter.summary: Reinforcement where agents learn to make decisions by taking actions in an environment to maximize cumulative rewards.
